 I thought I had made it crystal clear in the past that I support an originalist view of the constitution. 
 
 The constitution was essentially an agreement between the people forming a government. It was (and is) specifically designed to delegate a narrow range of powers to the government while protecting the rights of the people. Included in the constitution is a method for changing it which ensures that it will never be out of date, as well ensuring that it will not be changed on a whim, AND ensuring that the original spirit of the document, an agreement bewteen the people to empower a government, remains intact.
 
 When you have judges and courts making constitutional rulings that are CLEARLY beyond the boundries under which that agreement was made, they are essentially changing the constitution without the input of the people. At that point the constitution ceases to be an agreement among the people empowering a government and becomes a self written government charter.
 
 Michael Hodges has an interesting section on his page about trust in government:

As of May 2006, 76% have a low respect for Congress,

 58% have low respect for the media.
 
 78% believe the federal government has too much power;

 
 When 78% of a governments population feels that the government has too much power, that government is no longer governing with the consent of its citizens. It is governing in spite of them. 
 
 Is there really any doubt in your mind that as written and ratified, EVERYBODY is supposed to have the right to a trial? Is there really any doubt in your mind that as written and ratified, everybody is supposed to be safe from TORTURE by the US government? Do you really believe for even one second that our government was actually supposed to be able to split hairs over things like waterboarding? Do you really believe that as written and ratified the federal government was supposed to be able to supercede the state of california, overturning a popular measure passed by voters to allow private citizens to cultivate marajuana for their private use? 
 
 HELL NO. 
 
 Admittedly there have been some clever manipualtions and creative decpetions over the past couple hundred years in order to transform what was described by several newspapers at the time as "A simple document that can fit in a mans pocket that even a simpleton can fully understand" into a supposedly complex piece of work that you must spend millions of dollars on a trip to the supreme court in order to have interpeted. 
 
 This seems largely to be the result of a shift in paradigm in our judicial brach following WWII. Prior to WWII, judicial conventional wisdom was that in all matters, events and arguments must be viewed in the light most favorable to the citizen. The courts were largely seen, even by those in government, as at best a fair arbitrator between the government and its people and more likely as an ally to the citizen against the government. The primary mission of the courts was largely viewed as protectign the rights of the citizen. Following WWII, the paradigm shifted and the courts primary mission seemed to be preserving the power of the government.
